articles.title: Rocky Planet in Outer Orbit Challenges Planet Formation Theories
articles.summary: Astronomers have discovered a planetary system around the star LHS 1903 that defies conventional planet formation theories. Typically, in systems like our Solar System, rocky planets such as Earth orbit close to the star, while gas giants like Jupiter are found farther out. This pattern is explained by theories suggesting that intense stellar radiation strips gases from inner planets, leaving them rocky, while cooler outer regions allow gas accumulation. However, in the LHS 1903 system, researchers identified a rocky planet, LHS 1903 e, orbiting farthest from the star, alongside inner rocky and gas planets. Using data from telescopes like CHEOPS, the team ruled out explanations such as atmospheric stripping from collisions or planetary migration. Instead, they propose an 'inside out' formation model, where planets form sequentially as conditions change, with LHS 1903 e assembling late when gas was scarce. This discovery, published in Science, prompts a reevaluation of how and when rocky planets can develop in diverse environments.

articles.title: Observing a Star's Quiet Collapse into a Black Hole
articles.summary: Astronomers have directly observed a massive star, known as M31-2014-DS1, skip a supernova explosion and collapse into a black hole. Located about 2.5 million light-years away in the Andromeda Galaxy, this star was studied using data from NASA's NEOWISE mission and other telescopes from 2005 to 2023. The star brightened in infrared light in 2014, then its brightness dropped sharply by 2016, and by 2022-2023, it had nearly vanished in visible and near-infrared wavelengths, fading to one ten-thousandth of its former brightness. Researchers concluded that the core collapsed under gravity to form a black hole, with the outer layers pushed outward gradually. This provides detailed insights into how stellar black holes form, challenging the idea that all massive stars explode in supernovae. The findings, published in Science, may help explain why some stars collapse quietly while others explode. Lead author Kishalay De notes that light from debris around the black hole will be visible for decades with telescopes like the James Webb Space Telescope, offering a benchmark for future studies. The research also revisited a similar object, NGC 6946-BH1, highlighting the role of convection in understanding failed supernovae.

articles.title: How Brain Synchrony Influences Generosity in Decision-Making
articles.summary: A recent study published in PLOS Biology explored how brain stimulation can enhance altruistic behavior. Researchers, led by Jie Hu from East China Normal University in collaboration with the University of Zurich, recruited 44 participants to engage in a Dictator Game. In this game, individuals made 540 decisions on splitting money with another person, with varying payout amounts. During the task, the team applied transcranial alternating current stimulation to the frontal and parietal lobes of the brain, aiming to synchronize neuron firing patterns into gamma or alpha oscillations. They discovered that when gamma synchrony was strengthened between these regions, participants showed a modest increase in altruistic choices, sharing larger amounts even at personal cost. Using a computational model, the researchers found that stimulation shifted decision-making by increasing the weight placed on others' outcomes. Although neural activity wasn't directly measured, the findings suggest that synchronized brain activity plays a key role in social decisions. Coauthors like Christian Ruff and Marius Moisa highlighted that this demonstrates cause and effect, improving our understanding of brain mechanisms behind cooperation and generosity.

articles.title: Discovery of Self-Replicating RNA Sheds Light on Life's Origins
articles.summary: Researchers have identified a remarkably short RNA molecule, only 45 bases long, that can catalyze its own replication, a breakthrough in understanding the origin of life. RNA, which carries genetic information and acts as a catalyst, is central to the 'RNA world' hypothesis, suggesting early life relied on RNA for both heredity and metabolism. The ability to self-replicate is crucial for heritability, but previous catalytic RNAs, or ribozymes, were too long and inefficient to copy themselves fully. A French-UK team addressed this by searching for ligase ribozymes in short, random RNA sequences. They tested pools of 40-80 base RNAs, using a tag-based method to isolate those that could link small RNA fragments. After multiple rounds of selection and mutagenesis, they isolated QT-45, a ribozyme that efficiently adds bases to a template. This tiny molecule, derived from a 51-base precursor, demonstrates that short RNAs can function as polymerases, overcoming previous limitations of length and structural complexity. While it operates slowly, QT-45's ability to self-copy supports theories about how simple molecules could have initiated life on Earth, highlighting progress in synthetic biology and prebiotic chemistry.

articles.title: Uncovering the Role of Astrocytes in Spinal Cord Repair
articles.summary: Researchers at Cedars-Sinai have discovered a new biological repair process involving astrocytes, support cells in the central nervous system, that could revolutionize treatments for spinal cord injuries and neurological diseases. The study, published in Nature, identifies lesion-remote astrocytes (LRAs) located far from injury sites. These LRAs produce a protein called CCN1, which signals microglia, immune cells in the brain and spinal cord, to clean up debris from damaged nerve fibers. This cleanup is crucial for reducing inflammation and promoting tissue healing. Experiments on mice and human spinal cord samples showed that when CCN1 is removed, healing is impaired, leading to increased inflammation and poor recovery. The findings also apply to conditions like multiple sclerosis, suggesting that astrocytes play a broader role in central nervous system repair. This research highlights the potential for targeting astrocytes to develop therapies that enhance recovery after injuries and diseases, offering hope for patients with limited treatment options.

articles.title: Ariane 6 Rocket's First Heavy Launch Supports Amazon's Satellite Constellation
articles.summary: The Ariane 64, Europe's most powerful rocket variant, successfully launched for the first time, carrying 32 Amazon Leo satellites to low-Earth orbit. This mission from the Guiana Space Center in South America marked a milestone for European space capabilities, with the rocket generating over 3.4 million pounds of thrust using four solid rocket boosters. Amazon is deploying a large satellite broadband constellation called Amazon Leo, requiring over 3,200 satellites, and has booked launches across multiple providers including SpaceX, United Launch Alliance (ULA), and Arianespace. The Ariane 6 has ramped up quickly with six flights, but other rockets like ULA's Vulcan have faced delays and anomalies, such as a booster malfunction. Amazon faces a launch capacity shortage and is seeking additional options to meet regulatory deadlines for deploying half its constellation by July. The company has invested heavily in ULA's Vulcan rocket, but its launch rate remains uncertain.
